Advanced Vocabulary - Page 7

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 7

Continue expanding your advanced vocabulary with these sophisticated words that demonstrate intellectual precision and eloquent expression.

Navigation

This is page 7 of 12. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Fastidious

/fæˈstɪdiəs/

adjective

Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.

"She was fastidious about keeping her laboratory equipment clean."

Synonyms: meticulous, particular, scrupulous

Category: Precision

Fatuous

/ˈfætʃuəs/

adjective

Silly and pointless; lacking intelligence.

"His fatuous comments during the serious discussion were inappropriate."

Synonyms: foolish, silly, inane

Category: Intelligence

Fecund

/ˈfekənd/

adjective

Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile.

"The fecund imagination of the author produced dozens of novels."

Synonyms: fertile, productive, prolific

Category: Productivity

Felicitous

/fəˈlɪsɪtəs/

adjective

Pleasing and fortunate; well-chosen or apt.

"Her felicitous choice of words perfectly captured the mood."

Synonyms: apt, appropriate, fitting

Category: Appropriateness

Flagrant

/ˈfleɪɡrənt/

adjective

Conspicuously or obviously offensive; done openly and unashamedly.

"The referee's flagrant bias toward the home team was obvious to all."

Synonyms: blatant, obvious, glaring

Category: Obviousness

Garrulous

/ˈɡærələs/

adjective

Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.

"The garrulous passenger talked nonstop during the entire flight."

Synonyms: talkative, loquacious, chatty

Category: Communication

Gratuitous

/ɡrəˈtuɪtəs/

adjective

Uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted.

"The movie's gratuitous violence detracted from the storyline."

Synonyms: unnecessary, unwarranted, excessive

Category: Necessity

Gregarious

/ɡrɪˈɡeriəs/

adjective

Fond of the company of others; sociable.

"His gregarious nature made him popular at parties."

Synonyms: sociable, outgoing, friendly

Category: Personality

Hackneyed

/ˈhæknid/

adjective

Lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.

"The speech was full of hackneyed phrases and clichés."

Synonyms: clichéd, trite, overused

Category: Originality

Hegemony

/hɪˈɡemoʊni/

noun

Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.

"The empire established its hegemony over the entire region."

Synonyms: dominance, supremacy, control

Category: Power

Hyperbole

/haɪˈpɜːrbəli/

noun

Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally.

"When she said she could eat a horse, it was obvious hyperbole."

Synonyms: exaggeration, overstatement, embellishment

Category: Language

Iconoclast

/aɪˈkɑːnəklæst/

noun

A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.

"As an iconoclast, he questioned many traditional assumptions."

Synonyms: rebel, nonconformist, dissenter

Category: Rebellion
